An attempt to automate reliable running of susie even on hard problems

Source: R/susie_auto.R
susie_auto.Rd

An attempt to automate reliable running of susie even on hard problems

susie_auto(X, Y, L_init = 1, L_max = 512, verbose = FALSE,
  init_tol = 1, standardize = TRUE, intercept = TRUE,
  max_iter = 100, tol = 0.01, ...)

Arguments

X

an n by p matrix of covariates
Y

an n vector
L_init

the initial value of L to consider
L_max

the maximum value of L to consider
verbose

if true outputs some progress messages
init_tol

the tolerance to pass to susie during early runs (set big to run faster)
standardize

logical flag for whether to standardize columns of X to unit variance prior to fitting. Note that `prior_variance` specifies the prior on the coefficients of X after standardization (if performed). If you do not standardize you may need to think carefully about specifying `prior_variance`. Whatever the value of standardize, the coefficients (returned from `coef`) are for X on the original input scale. Any column of X that has zero variance is not standardized, but left as is.
intercept

Should intercept be fitted (default=TRUE) or set to zero (FALSE)
max_iter

maximum number of iterations to perform
tol

convergence tolerance

Details

Currently runs a 3-stage strategy for each L: first fit susie with very small residual error, then estimate residual error, then estimate prior variance. If the last step estimates some prior variances to be 0 then stop. Otherwise double L and repeat. Initial runs are done with lax tolerance (init_tol); final run done with default tolerance.

Contents

  • Arguments
  • Details

Developed by Gao Wang, Peter Carbonetto, Yuxin Zou, Kaiqian Zhang, Matthew Stephens.
